arguments.description: Indicates the numeric variable that SAS sets to the position of the VSAM key field. This option enables you to read keys without knowing the key position in advance. This variable is set to the column number (starting from 1).

arguments.name: KEYVALUE=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies the key value with which to begin reading an indexed file.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable that SAS sets to the length of the current input line.

arguments.name: LINE=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable that SAS sets to the line location of the input pointer in the input buffer. Like automatic variables, the LINE= variable is not written to the data set.

arguments.name: LINESIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the record length that is available to the INPUT statement.

arguments.name: LRECL=
arguments.description: Specifies the logical record length.

arguments.name: MBC=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies the size of the I/O buffers that OpenVMS RMS allocates for a particular file. The value can range from 0 to 127 and represents the number of blocks used for each buffer. By default, this option is set to 0 and the default values for the process are used. The MBC= option (multiblock count) is used for both input and output to control the allocation for a particular file. If you want to control the allocation size for all the external files used during the current SAS session, you can use the MBC= option in every FILE, FILENAME, or INFILE statement. You can also use the DCL SET RMS_DEFAULT command to specify a process default, and let the SAS values default to the process's default values.

arguments.name: MBF=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Specifies the number of I/O buffers you want OpenVMS RMS to allocate for a particular file. The value can range from 0 to 127 and represents the number of buffers used. By default, this option is set to a value of 2. If a value of 0 is specified, the default value for the process is used. The MBF= option (multibuffer count) is used for both input and output to control the number of buffers allocated for a particular file. If you want to control the number of buffers allocated for all the external files used during the SAS session, you can use the MBF= option in every FILE, FILENAME, or INFILE statement. The DCL SET RMS_DEFAULT command can be used to specify a process default. Then, you can let the SAS values default to the process's default values.

arguments.name: MESSAGE
arguments.description: Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option indicates the type of pipe. BYTE is the default value.

arguments.name: MISSOVER
arguments.description: Prevents an INPUT statement from reading a new input data record if it does not find values in the current input line for all the variables in the statement.

arguments.name: MOD
arguments.description: Indicates that data written to the file should be appended to the file

arguments.name: MVS
arguments.description: [type] For z/OS data sets.

arguments.name: N=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of lines that are available to the input pointer at one time.

arguments.name: NBYTE=
arguments.description: Specifies the StatementOptionName of a variable that contains the number of bytes to read from a file when you are reading data in stream record format (RECFM=S in the FILENAME statement).

arguments.name: NEW
arguments.description: Indicates that a new file is to be opened for output. If the file already exists, then it is deleted and re-created.

arguments.name: NOBLOCK
arguments.description: Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option indicates whether the client is to wait if no data is currently available. BLOCK is the default value.

arguments.name: NOEXPANDTABS
arguments.description: Specifies not to expand tab characters to the standard tab setting, which is set at 8-column intervals that start at column 9.

arguments.name: NOPAD
arguments.description: SAS does not pad the records that are read from an external file with blanks to the length that is specified in the LRECL= option.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Specifies that the input file does not contain carriage-control characters.

arguments.name: NOTAB
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Instructs SAS to ignore tab characters between variables.

arguments.name: NRLS
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Specifies not to use record-level sharing (RLS) to open an RLS-eligible data set (INFILE only).

arguments.name: OBS=
arguments.description: Use OBS= with FIRSTOBS= to read a range of records from the middle of a file.

arguments.name: record-number
arguments.description: Specifies the record number of the last record to read in an input file that is read sequentially.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of observations to process, which will be at least as large as the largest signed, 32-bit integer.

arguments.name: OLD
arguments.description: Indicates that a new file is to be opened for output. If the file already exists, then the previous contents of the file are replaced.

arguments.name: PAD
arguments.description: SAS pads the records that are read from an external file with blanks to the length that is specified in the LRECL= option.

arguments.name: PASSWD=
arguments.description: Gives the appropriate password for a VSAM data set that has password protection.

arguments.name: PIPE
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies an unnamed pipe. Note: Some operating environments do not support pipes.

arguments.name: PLOTTER
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies an unbuffered graphics output device.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: Specifies that the input file contains carriage-control characters.

arguments.name: PRINTER
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies a printer or printer spool file.

arguments.name: RBA=
arguments.description: Specifies a numeric variable that you set to the relative byte address (RBA) of the data record that you want to read. The RBA= option indicates that addressed direct access is being used; it is appropriate for KSDS and ESDS. If you specify the CONTROLINTERVAL option, you can use the RBA= option to access control records in an RRDS (INFILE only).

arguments.name: RC4STOP
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Stops the DATA step from executing if a return code greater than 4 is returned by the operating environment when the VSAM data set is opened.

arguments.name: RECFM=
arguments.description: [Windows/UNIX Host Option] Specifies the record format of the external file.
arguments.help: RECFM=F | P | S | V | N | s370V | S370VB | S370VBS | STREAMLF

arguments.name: F
arguments.description: Fixed-record format

arguments.name: P
arguments.description: Print format.

arguments.name: S
arguments.description: Stream-record format.

arguments.name: V
arguments.description: Variable-record format (the default)

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Indicates binary format and causes the file to be treated as a byte stream. If LRECL is not specified, by default SAS reads 256 bytes at a time from the file.

arguments.name: s370V
arguments.description: Indicates the variable S370 record format (V).

arguments.name: S370VB
arguments.description: Indicates the variable block S370 record format (VB).

arguments.name: S370VBS
arguments.description: Indicates the variable block with spanned records S370 record format (VBS).

arguments.name: STREAMLF
arguments.description: [For OpenVMS] Specifies StreamLF record format. Records are delimited by LF.

arguments.name: RECORDS=
arguments.description: Defines a numeric variable that SAS sets to the number of logical records in a VSAM data set that has been opened for input.

arguments.name: RECORG=
arguments.description: [z/OS Host Option] Specifies the organization of records in a new VSAM data set. Use this option only if SMS is active.

arguments.name: KS
arguments.description: Specifies a VSAM key-sequenced data set.

arguments.name: ES
arguments.description: Specifies a VSAM entry-sequenced data set.

arguments.name: RR
arguments.description: Specifies a VSAM relative-record data set.

arguments.name: LS
arguments.description: Specifies a VSAM linear-space data set.

arguments.name: RESET
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Indicates that the VSAM file is reset to empty (no records) when it is opened. This option applies only to loading a VSAM data set that has been marked REUSE. You cannot use this option if the data set contains an alternate index.

arguments.name: RETRY=
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option]

arguments.name: RRN=
arguments.description: Defines a numeric variable that you set to the relative record number (RRN) of the record that you want to read or write. This option indicates that keyed direct access is being used; it is appropriate for RRDS only.

arguments.name: SCANOVER
arguments.description: Causes the INPUT statement to scan the input data records until the character string that is specified in the @'character-string' expression is found.

arguments.name: SEQUENTIAL
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Specifies sequential VSAM record retrieval when either the RBA= (for an ESDS) or the RRN= option (for an RRDS) is specified (INFILE only).

arguments.name: SERVER
arguments.description: [Windows Host Option] Is used only in the context of named pipes. This option specifies the mode of a named pipe. The default value is SERVER.

arguments.name: SHAREBUFFERS
arguments.description: Specifies that the FILE statement and the INFILE statement share the same buffer.

arguments.name: SHR=
arguments.description: [OpenVMS Host Option] Overrides the default file-sharing attributes used for external files. With this option, you can indicate the access level you want to give other users. You can allow READ, WRITE, UPDATE, and DELETE access (as well as no access). By default with external files, files opened for input allow shared read access, and files opened for output or UPDATE do not allow shared access. However, you can allow other users to have READ and WRITE access to a file that you are opening for input only. To accomplish this, use the SHR= option. The syntax of the SHR= option is SHR=share-option-list where share-option-list can be one of the following: DEL specifies DELETE access. GET specifies shared READ access. NONE specifies no shared access. PUT specifies shared WRITE access. UPD specifies UPDATE access. You can combine these values in any order. For example, specifying the following indicates that you want shared DELETE, READ, and WRITE access:

arguments.name: SKIP
arguments.description: [VSAM Option] Indicates skip-sequential processing of VSAM files. Skip-sequential processing finds the first record whose value is the same as the value specified by the KEY= option; records are read sequentially thereafter (INFILE only).

arguments.name: START=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable whose value SAS uses as the first column number of the record that the PUT _INFILE_ statement writes. Like automatic variables, the START variable is not written to the data set.

arguments.name: STOPOVER
arguments.description: Causes the DATA step to stop processing if an INPUT statement reaches the end of the current record without finding values for all variables in the statement.

arguments.name: TAPE
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies a tape drive.

arguments.name: TEMP
arguments.description: [device-type] Creates a temporary file that exists only as long as the filename is assigned.

arguments.name: TERMINAL
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies the user's terminal.

arguments.name: TERMSTR=
arguments.description: [Windows/UNIX Host Option] Specifies the end-of-line character for the file. Use this option to share files between the UNIX and Windows operating environments.
arguments.help: TERMSTR=CR | CRLF | LF | NULL | NONE | NL | LFCR | CRNL

arguments.name: CR
arguments.description: Carriage return (CR).

arguments.name: CRLF
arguments.description: Carriage return (CR) followed by line feed (LF).

arguments.name: LF
arguments.description: Line feed only (the default).

arguments.name: NULL
arguments.description: NULL character (0x00).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Record terminators are not used. This parameter provides the same function as FILEDATA=BINARY.

arguments.name: NL
arguments.description: The newline character (x'15') is used as the record terminator. This parameter provides the same function as FILEDATA=TEXT.

arguments.name: LFCR
arguments.description: The sequence LF followed by CR is used as the record terminator.

arguments.name: CRNL
arguments.description: The sequence CR followed by NL is used as the record terminator.

arguments.name: TRUNCOVER
arguments.description: Overrides the default behavior of the INPUT statement when an input data record is shorter than the INPUT statement expects. By default, the INPUT statement automatically reads the next input data record. TRUNCOVER enables you to read variable-length records when some records are shorter than the INPUT statement expects. Variables without any values assigned are set to missing.

arguments.name: UNBUFFERED
arguments.description: Tells SAS not to perform a buffered ("look ahead") read.

arguments.name: UPDATE=
arguments.description: Defines a numeric SAS variable that indicates that not every record that it reads is to be updated. Use this option when you are updating records in a VSAM data set (INFILE only). When an INFILE and a FILE statement reference the same VSAM data set, records are retrieved for update by default.

arguments.name: UPRINTER
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies a Universal Printing printer definition StatementOptionName.

arguments.name: VSAM
arguments.description: [type] For VSAM files.

arguments.name: VTOC
arguments.description: [type] For a Volume Table of Contents (VTOC).

arguments.name: _INFILE_=
arguments.description: Specifies a character variable that references the contents of the current input buffer for this INFILE statement.

statements.name: INFORMAT
statements.description: Associates informats with variables.

arguments.name: DEFAULT=
arguments.description: Specifies a temporary default informat for reading values of the variables that are listed in the INFORMAT statement. If no variable is specified, then the DEFAULT= informat specification applies a temporary default informat for reading values of all the variables of that type included in the DATA step. Numeric informats are applied to numeric variables, and character informats are applied to character variables. These default informats apply only to the current DATA step. A DEFAULT= informat specification applies to o variables that are not named in an INFORMAT or ATTRIB statement o variables that are not permanently associated with an informat within a SAS data set o variables that are not read with an explicit informat in the current DATA step. Default: If you omit DEFAULT=, SAS uses w.d as the default numeric informat and $w. as the default character informat. Restriction: Use this argument only in a DATA step.

statements.name: INPUT
statements.description: Describes the arrangement of values in the input data record and assigns input values to the corresponding SAS variables.

statements.name: KEEP
statements.description: Specifies the variables to include in output SAS data sets.

statements.name: LABEL
statements.description: Identifies a statement that is referred to by another statement.

statements.name: LEAVE
statements.description: Stops processing the current loop and resumes with the next statement in the sequence.

statements.name: LENGTH
statements.description: Specifies the number of bytes for storing variables.

arguments.name: DEFAULT=
arguments.description: Changes the default number of bytes that SAS uses to store the values of any newly created numeric variables.

statements.name: LINK
statements.description: Directs program execution immediately to the statement label that is specified and, if followed by a RETURN statement, returns execution to the statement that follows the LINK statement.

statements.name: LIST
statements.description: Writes to the SAS log the input data record for the observation that is being processed.

statements.name: LOSS
statements.description: The LOSS statement specifies the name of the response or loss variable whose distribution needs to be modeled. You can also specify additional options to indicate any truncation or censoring of the response. The specification of response variable is optional if at least one type of censoring is specified. You must specify a response variable if no censoring is specified. If you specify more than one LOSS statement, then the first statement is used.

arguments.name: LEFTCENSORED=
arguments.description: Specifies the left-censoring variable or a global left-censoring limit.

arguments.name: LEFTTRUNCATED=
arguments.description: Specifies the left-truncation variable or a global left-truncation threshold.

arguments.name: RIGHTCENSORED=
arguments.description: Specifies the right-censoring variable or a global right-censoring limit.

arguments.name: RIGHTTRUNCATED=
arguments.description: Specifies the right-truncation variable or a global right-truncation threshold.

statements.name: MERGE
statements.description: Joins observations from two or more SAS data sets into a single observation.

arguments.name: BUFSIZE=
arguments.help: BUFSIZE=n | nK | nM | nG | hexX | MIN | MAX

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: Names and creates a temporary variable that contains an end-of-file indicator.

arguments.name: FIRSTOBS=
arguments.help: FIRSTOBS=n | nK | nM | nG | hexX | MIN | MAX

arguments.name: OBS=
arguments.help: OBS=n | nK | nM | nG | nT | hexX | MIN | MAX

statements.name: MODIFY
statements.description: Replaces, deletes, and appends observations in an existing SAS data set in place but does not create an additional copy.

arguments.name: CUREOBS=
arguments.description: Creates and names a variable that contains the observation number that was just read from the data set.

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: Creates and names a temporary variable that contains an end-of-file indicator.

arguments.name: KEY=
arguments.description: Specifies a simple or composite index of the SAS data file that is being modified. The KEY= argument retrieves observations from that SAS data file based on index values that are supplied by like-named variables in another source of information.

arguments.name: KEYRESET=
arguments.description: Controls whether a KEY= search should begin at the top of the index for the data set that is being read. When the value of the KEYRESET variable is 1, the index lookup begins at the top of the index. When the value of the KEYRESET variable is 0, the index lookup is not reset and the lookup continues where the prior lookup ended.

arguments.name: NOBS=
arguments.description: Creates and names a temporary variable whose value is usually the total number of observations in the input data set. For certain SAS views, SAS cannot determine the number of observations. In these cases, SAS sets the value of the NOBS= variable to the largest positive integer value available in the operating environment.

arguments.name: POINT=
arguments.description: Reads SAS data sets using random (direct) access by observation number. variable names a variable whose value is the number of the observation to read. The POINT= variable is available anywhere in the DATA step, but it is not added to any SAS data set.

arguments.name: UNIQUE
arguments.description: Causes a KEY= search always to begin at the top of the index for the data file being modified.

arguments.name: UPDATEMODE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether missing variable values in a transaction data set are to be allowed to replace existing variable values in a master data set.

arguments.name: MISSINGCHECK
arguments.description: Prevents missing variable values in a transaction data set from replacing values in a master data set.

arguments.name: NOMISSINGCHECK
arguments.description: Allows missing variable values in a transaction data set to replace values in a master data set by preventing the check from being performed.

statements.name: NLOPTIONS
statements.description: The SEVSELECT procedure uses the nonlinear optimization (NLO) subsystem to perform nonlinear optimization of the likelihood function to obtain the estimates of distribution and regression parameters. You can use the NLOPTIONS statement to control different aspects of this optimization process. If you specify more than one NLOPTIONS statement, then the first statement is used.

arguments.name: ABSCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion. The default value of r is the negative square root of the largest double-precision value, which serves only as a protection against overflows.

arguments.name: ABSFCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion. The default value is r=0. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can be terminated.

arguments.name: ABSGCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute gradient convergence criterion. The default value is r=1E-5. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can be terminated.

arguments.name: ABSXCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute parameter convergence criterion. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can terminate.

arguments.name: FCONV2=
arguments.description: Specifies another function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies a relative function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the FSIZE parameter of the relative function and relative gradient termination criteria. The default value is r=0.

arguments.name: GCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies a relative gradient convergence criterion.

arguments.name: MAXFUNC=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number i of function calls in the optimization process. The default values are: TRUREG, NRRIDG, NEWRAP: 125 QUANEW, DBLDOG: 500 CONGRA: 1000 NMSIMP: 3000

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number i of iterations in the optimization process. The default values are: TRUREG, NRRIDG, NEWRAP: 50 QUANEW, DBLDOG: 200 CONGRA: 400 NMSIMP: 1000 These default values are also valid when i is specified as a missing value.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper limit of r seconds of CPU time for the optimization process. The default value is the largest floating-point double representation of your computer. Note that the time specified by the MAXTIME= option is checked only once at the end of each iteration. Therefore, the actual running time can be much longer than that specified by the MAXTIME= option. The actual running time includes the rest of the time needed to finish the iteration and the time needed to generate the output of the results.

arguments.name: MINITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the minimum number of iterations. The default value is 0. If you request more iterations than are actually needed for convergence to a stationary point, the optimization algorithms can behave strangely. For example, the effect of rounding errors can prevent the algorithm from continuing for the required number of iterations.

arguments.name: TECHNIQUE=
arguments.description: Specifies the optimization technique.
arguments.help: TECHNIQUE=CONGRA | DBLDOG | NMSIMP | NEWRAP | NRRIDG | QUANEW | TRUREG | NONE

arguments.name: CONGRA
arguments.description: Performs a conjugate-gradient optimization.

arguments.name: DBLDOG
arguments.description: Performs a version of double-dogleg optimization.

arguments.name: NMSIMP
arguments.description: Performs a Nelder-Mead simplex optimization.

arguments.name: NEWRAP
arguments.description: Performs a Newton-Raphson optimization that combines a line-search algorithm with ridging.

arguments.name: NRRIDG
arguments.description: Performs a Newton-Raphson optimization with ridging.

arguments.name: QUANEW
arguments.description: Performs a quasi-Newton optimization

arguments.name: TRUREG
arguments.description: Performs a trust region optimization. This is the default estimation method.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Does not perform any optimization. This option can be used as follows: – to perform a grid search without optimization – to compute estimates and predictions that cannot be obtained efficiently with any of the optimization techniques

arguments.name: XCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative parameter convergence criterion. For all techniques except NMSIMP, termination requires a small relative parameter change in subsequent iterations. The default value is r=1E-8 for the NMSIMP technique and r=0 otherwise. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can be terminated.

arguments.name: XSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the XSIZE parameter of the relative parameter termination criterion. The default value is r=0.

statements.name: OTHERWISE
statements.description: Specifies a statement to be executed if no WHEN condition is met.

arguments.name: DO
arguments.description: Action statement.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: The OUTPUT statement creates the output data table that contains the estimates of scoring functions and quantiles.

arguments.name: COPYVARS=
arguments.description: Specifies the names of the variables that you want to copy from the input DATA= data table to the OUT= data table. If you want to specify more than one name, then separate them by spaces.

arguments.name: FUNCTIONS=
arguments.description: Specifies the scoring functions that you want to estimate.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output data table for PROC SEVSELECT to use. You must specify this option before any other options. CAS-libref.data-table is a two-level name, where

arguments.name: QUANTILES=
arguments.description: Specifies the quantiles that you want to estimate. To use this option, for each distribution that you specify in the DIST statement, the FCMP function D_QUANTILE must be defined in the search path that you specify by using the CMPLIB= system option.

statements.name: OUTSCORELIB
statements.description: The OUTSCORELIB statement specifies the library to write scoring functions to. Scoring functions enable you to easily compute a distribution function on the fitted parameters of the distribution without going through a potentially complex process of extracting the fitted parameter estimates from other output such as the OUTEST= data set that is created by PROC SEVSELECT.

arguments.name: OUTLIB=
arguments.description: Names the FCMP library to contain the scoring functions. PROC SEVSELECT writes the scoring functions to the FCMP library named fcmp-library-name. If a library or data set named fcmp-libraryname already exists, PROC SEVSELECT deletes it before proceeding

arguments.name: COMMONPACKAGE
arguments.description: Requests that only one common package be created to contain all the scoring functions.

arguments.name: OUTBYID=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the unique identifier for each BY group. This unique identifier is used as part of the name of the package or scoring function for each distribution. This is a required option when you specify a BY statement in PROC SEVSELECT.

statements.name: PUT
statements.description: Writes lines to the SAS log, to the SAS output window, or to an external location that is specified in the most recent FILE statement.

arguments.name: OVERPRINT
arguments.description: Causes the values that follow the keyword OVERPRINT to print on the most recently written output line.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: Writes the values of all variables, which includes automatic variables, that are defined in the current DATA step by using named output.

arguments.name: _BLANKPAGE_
arguments.description: Advances the pointer to the first line of a new page, even when the pointer is positioned on the first line and the first column of a new page.

arguments.name: _INFILE_
arguments.description: Writes the last input data record that is read either from the current input file or from the data lines that follow a DATELINES statement.

arguments.name: _ODS_
arguments.description: Moves data values for all columns (as defined by the ODS option in the FILE statement) into a special buffer, from which it is eventually written to the data component. The ODS option in the FILE statement defines the structure of the data component that holds the results of the DATA step.

arguments.name: _PAGE_
arguments.description: Advances the pointer to the first line of a new page. SAS automatically begins a new page when a line exceeds the current PAGESIZE= value.

statements.name: PUTLOG
statements.description: Writes a message to the SAS log.

statements.name: RENAME
statements.description: Specifies new names for variables in output SAS data sets.

statements.name: REPLACE
statements.description: Replaces an observation in the same location.

statements.name: RETAIN
statements.description: Causes a variable that is created by an INPUT or assignment statement to retain its value from one iteration of the DATA step to the next.

statements.name: RETURN
statements.description: Stops executing statements at the current point in the DATA step and returns to a predetermined point in the step.

statements.name: RSUBMIT
statements.description: Marks the beginning of a block of statements that a client session submits to a server session for execution.

statements.name: SCALEMODEL
statements.description: The SCALEMODEL statement specifies regression effects. A regression effect is formed from one or more regressor variables according to effect construction rules.

arguments.name: DFMIXTURE=
arguments.description: Specifies the method for computing representative estimates of the cumulative distribution function (CDF).

arguments.name: FULL
arguments.description: Specifies that the representative distribution be the mixture of N distributions such that each distribution has a scale value that is implied by each of the N observations that are used for estimation. This method is the slowest.

arguments.name: MEAN
arguments.description: Specifies that the representative distribution be the one-point mixture of the distribution whose scale value is the mean of the N scale values that are implied by the N observations that are used for estimation. If you do not specify the DFMIXTURE= option, then this method is used by default. This is also the fastest method.

arguments.name: QUANTILE
arguments.description: Syntax: QUANTILE < (K=q) > specifies that the representative distribution be the mixture of a fixed number of distributions whose scale values are the quantiles from the sample of N scale values that are implied by the N observations in the current BY group (or in the entire DATA= data set if the BY statement is not specified). You can use the K= option to specify the number of distributions in the mixture. If you specify K=q, then the mixture contains (q - 1) distributions such that each distribution has as its scale one of the (q - 1)-quantiles.

arguments.name: RANDOM
arguments.description: Syntax: RANDOM < (random-method-options) > specifies that the representative distribution be the mixture of a fixed number of distributions whose scale values are the scale values that are implied by a randomly chosen subset of the set of all observations in the current BY group (or in the entire DATA= data set if the BY statement is not specified). The same subset of observations is used for each distribution family. You can specify the following random-method-options to specify how the subset is chosen: K=r specifies the number of distributions to include in the mixture. If you do not specify this option, then PROC SEVSELECT uses the default of 15. SEED=number specifies the seed that is used to generate the uniform random sample of observation indices. If you do not specify this option, then PROC SEVSELECT generates a seed internally that is based on the current value of the system clock.

arguments.name: INCLUDE=
arguments.description: Forces effects to be included in all models. If you specify INCLUDE=n, then the first n effects that are listed in the SCALEMODEL statement are included in all models. If you specify INCLUDE=single-effect or INCLUDE=(single-effect), then the specified effects are forced into all models. The INCLUDE= option has no effect if you do not specify the SELECTION statement.

arguments.name: INFORMATIVE
arguments.description: Models missing values by using extra model effects. These effects consist of dummy variables that take the value 1 when the value of a continuous model variable involved in the effect is missing, and take the value 0 otherwise. The missing value in the original model effect is replaced by the average value of the effect for the nonmissing values.

arguments.name: OFFSET=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the offset variable in the scale regression model. An offset variable is a regressor variable whose regression coefficient is known to be 1.

arguments.name: START=
arguments.description: Specifies how to begin the selection process in the FORWARD, FORWARDSWAP, and STEPWISE selection methods from the initial model that you designate. If you specify START=n, then the starting model consists of the first n effects that are listed in the SCALEMODEL statement. If you specify START=single-effect or START=(single-effect), then the starting model consists of these specified effects.

statements.name: SELECT
statements.description: Executes one of several statements or groups of statements.

statements.name: SELECTION
statements.description: The SELECTION statement performs model selection by examining whether effects should be added to or removed from the model according to rules that are defined by model selection methods.
statements.help: SELECTION <ADAPTIVE <(GAMMA=nonnegative number)>> <CHOOSE=<AIC | AICC | SBC>> <METHOD=<BACKWARD | FORWARD | FORWARDSWAP>... > ...

arguments.name: ADAPTIVE=
arguments.description: Applies adaptive weights to each of the coefficients when METHOD=LASSO. Ordinary least squares estimates of the model parameters are used to form the adaptive weights. You use the GAMMA= option to specify the power transformation that is applied to the parameters in forming the adaptive weights. By default, GAMMA=1.

arguments.name: CHOOSE=
arguments.description: Chooses from the list of models (at each step of the selection process) the model that yields the best value of the specified criterion.

arguments.name: AIC
arguments.description: Specifies Akaike’s information criterion.

arguments.name: AICC
arguments.description: Specifies the corrected Akaike’s information criterion.

arguments.name: SBC
arguments.description: Specifies the Schwarz Bayesian information criterion.

arguments.name: COMPETITIVE
arguments.description: [method-option to be enclosed in parenthesis] Is applicable as a method-option only when METHOD=STEPWISE. If you specify the COMPETITIVE option, then the SELECT= criterion is evaluated for all models in which an effect currently in the model is dropped or an effect not yet in the model is added.

arguments.name: DETAILS=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of detail to be produced about the selection process. The default is DETAILS= SUMMARY.

arguments.name: SUMMARY
arguments.description: Produces a summary table that shows the effect that is added or removed at each step along with the criteria specified in the SELECT=, CHOOSE=, and STOP= method-options. The summary table is produced by default if you do not specify the DETAILS= option.

arguments.name: STEPS
arguments.description: Syntax: DETAILS=STEPS<(CANDIDATES(ALL | n))> Produces the preceding summary table and displays the results from fitting each model at each step. If you specify STEPS(CANDIDATES(n)), then the best n candidates are shown. If you specify STEPS(CANDIDATES(ALL)), then all candidates are shown.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Produces the preceding tables and a detailed listing of all candidates at each step along with their ranking in terms of the selection criterion for addition to or removal from the model.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that no details be produced about the selection process.

arguments.name: FAST
arguments.description: [method-option to be enclosed in parenthesis] Implements the computational algorithm of Lawless and Singhal (1978) to compute a first-order approximation to the remaining slope estimates for each subsequent elimination of a variable from the model. When applied in backward selection, this option essentially leads to approximating the selection process as the selection process of a linear regression model in which the crossproducts matrix equals the Hessian matrix in the full model under consideration. This option is available only when METHOD=BACKWARD is specified. It is computationally efficient because the model is not fit after removal of each effect.

arguments.name: HIERARCHY=
arguments.description: Specifies whether and how the model hierarchy requirement is applied. You can specify that only classification effects, or both classification and continuous effects, be subject to the hierarchy requirement. This option is ignored unless you also specify one of the following options: METHOD=FORWARD, METHOD=BACKWARD, or METHOD=STEPWISE.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that model hierarchy not be maintained. Any single effect can enter or leave the model at any step of the selection process.

arguments.name: SINGLE
arguments.description: Specifies that only one effect enter or leave the model at one time, subject to the model hierarchy requirement.

arguments.name: SINGLECLASS
arguments.description: Is the same as HIERARCHY=SINGLE except that only CLASS effects are subject to the hierarchy requirement.

arguments.name: LSCOEFFS
arguments.description: [method-option to be enclosed in parenthesis] Requests a hybrid version of the LAR and LASSO methods, in which the sequence of models is determined by the LAR or LASSO algorithm but the coefficients of the parameters for the model at any step are determined by using ordinary least squares.

arguments.name: MAXEFFECTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of effects in any model that is considered during the selection process. This option is ignored when METHOD=BACKWARD is specified.

arguments.name: MAXSTEPS=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of selection steps that are performed. The default value of n is the number of effects in the SCALEMODEL or MODEL statement when METHOD=FORWARD or METHOD=BACKWARD.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies the selection method to use.

arguments.name: BACKWARD
arguments.description: Specifies the backward elimination method.

arguments.name: FORWARD
arguments.description: Specifies the forward selection method.

arguments.name: FORWARDSWAP
arguments.description: Specifies forward-swap selection, which is an extension of the forward selection method.

arguments.name: STEPWISE
arguments.description: specifies the stepwise regression method.

arguments.name: MINEFFECTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the minimum number of effects in any model that is considered during backward selection. This option is ignored unless METHOD=BACKWARD is specified.

arguments.name: ORDERSELECT
arguments.description: Specifies that effects in the selected model are displayed in the order in which they first entered the model. If you do not specify the ORDERSELECT option, then effects in the selected model are displayed in the order in which they appear in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Controls the selection process plots that are produced through ODS Graphics. Each global-plot-option applies to all plots that the SELECTION statement generates, unless you alter the option by using a specific plot option that follows a plot-request. You can specify the following global-plot-options:

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: produces all relevant plots.

arguments.name: COEFFICIENTS
arguments.description: Syntax: COEFFICIENTS | COEFFICIENTPANEL <(UNPACK | UNPACKPANEL)> Creates a panel of two plots. The upper plot shows the progression of the parameter values as the selection process proceeds. The lower plot shows the progression of the CHOOSE= criterion.

arguments.name: CRITERIA
arguments.description: Syntax: CRITERIA | CRITERIONPANEL <(UNPACK | UNPACKPANEL)> Creates a panel of model fit criteria. If you specify the UNPACK option, then each criterion progression is shown in a separate plot.

arguments.name: FITBYROLE
arguments.description: Plots the progression of a fit statistic on the training, test, and validation data. The fit statistic that is displayed depends on the type of model that is being fit. The fit by role plot is not produced if you do not specify a PARTITION statement.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppress all selection process plots, even if you specify other plot options.

arguments.name: SELECT=
arguments.description: Specifies the criterion that the procedure uses to determine the order in which effects enter or leave at each step of the selection method. For each step, the effect whose addition to or removal from the current model yields the maximum improvement in the specified criterion is selected. You can use the traditional significance-level approach by specifying the SL criterion; for other supported criteria, see the chapter for the relevant procedure. This option is not valid when METHOD=LAR or METHOD=LASSO.

arguments.name: AIC
arguments.description: Specifies Akaike’s information criterion.

arguments.name: AICC
arguments.description: Specifies the corrected Akaike’s information criterion.

arguments.name: SBC
arguments.description: Specifies the Schwarz Bayesian information criterion.

arguments.name: SLENTRY=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level for entry when STOP=SL or SELECT=SL. By default, SLENTRY=0.05.

arguments.name: SLSTAY=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level for staying in the model when STOP=SL or SELECT=SL.

arguments.name: STOP=
arguments.description: Specifies a criterion that is used to stop the selection process.

arguments.name: SL
arguments.description: Stops the selection process at the step where the significance level of the candidate for entry is greater than the SLENTRY= value for addition steps when METHOD=FORWARD or METHOD=STEPWISE and where the significance level of the candidate for removal is greater than the SLSTAY= value when METHOD=BACKWARD or METHOD=STEPWISE.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Stops the selection process if no suitable add or drop candidates can be found or if a size-based limit is reached.

arguments.name: criterion
arguments.description: Stops the selection process if the selection process produces a local extremum of this criterion or if a size-based limit is reached.

arguments.name: STOPHORIZON=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of consecutive steps at which the STOP= criterion must worsen in order for a local extremum to be detected. The stop horizon value is ignored if you also specify STOP=NONE or STOP=SL. For example, suppose that STOP=AIC and the sequence of AIC values at steps 1 to 6 of a selection are 10, 7, 4, 6, 5, 2. If STOPHORIZON=2, then the AIC criterion is deemed to have a local minimum at step 3 because the AIC value at the next two steps are greater than the value 4 that occurs at step 3. However, if STOPHORIZON=3, then the value at step 3 is not deemed to be a local minimum because the AIC value at step 6 is lower than the AIC value at step 3. When METHOD=LAR or METHOD=LASSO, n is ignored and STOPHORIZON=1 is used. By default, STOPHORIZON=3.

statements.name: SET
statements.description: Reads an observation from one or more SAS data sets.

arguments.name: BUFSIZE=
arguments.help: BUFSIZE=n | nK | nM | nG | hexX | MIN | MAX

arguments.name: CUREOBS=
arguments.description: Creates and names a variable that contains the observation number that was just read from the data set.

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: Creates and names a temporary variable that contains an end-of-file indicator. The variable, which is initialized to zero, is set to 1 when SET reads the last observation of the last data set listed. This variable is not added to any new data set.

arguments.name: FIRSTOBS=
arguments.help: FIRSTOBS=n | nK | nM | nG | hexX | MIN | MAX

arguments.name: GENMAX=
arguments.description: Requests generations for a data set and specifies the maximum number of versions.

arguments.name: INDSNAME=
arguments.description: Creates and names a variable that stores the name of the SAS data set from which the current observation is read. The stored name can be a data set name or a physical name. The physical name is the name by which the operating environment recognizes the file.

arguments.name: KEY=
arguments.description: Provides nonsequential access to observations in a SAS data set, which are based on the value of an index variable or a key.

arguments.name: KEYRESET=
arguments.description: Controls whether a KEY= search should begin at the top of the index for the data set that is being read. When the value of the KEYRESET variable is 1, the index lookup begins at the top of the index. When the value of the KEYRESET variable is 0, the index lookup is not reset and the lookup continues where the prior lookup ended.

arguments.name: NOBS=
arguments.description: Creates and names a temporary variable whose value is usually the total number of observations in the input data set or data sets. If more than one data set is listed in the SET statement, NOBS= the total number of observations in the data sets that are listed. The number of observations includes those observations that are marked for deletion but are not yet deleted.

arguments.name: OBS=
arguments.help: OBS=n | nK | nM | nG | nT | hexX | MIN | MAX

arguments.name: OPEN=
arguments.description: Allows you to delay the opening of any concatenated SAS data sets until they are ready to be processed.

arguments.name: IMMEDIATE
arguments.description: During the compilation phase, opens all data sets that are listed in the SET statement.

arguments.name: DEFER
arguments.description: Opens the first data set during the compilation phase, and opens subsequent data sets during the execution phase. When the DATA step reads and processes all observations in a data set, it closes the data set and opens the next data set in the list.

arguments.name: POINT=
arguments.description: Specifies a temporary variable whose numeric value determines which observation is read. POINT= causes the SET statement to use random (direct) access to read a SAS data set.

arguments.name: READ=
arguments.description: Assigns a read password to a SAS file and enables access to a read-protected SAS file.

statements.name: STOP
statements.description: Stops execution of the current DATA step.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: The WEIGHT statement specifies the name of a variable whose values represent the weight of each observation. PROC SEVSELECT associates a weight of w to each observation, where w is the value of the WEIGHT variable for the observation. If the weight value is missing or less than or equal to 0, then the observation is ignored and a warning is written to the SAS log. When the WEIGHT statement is not specified, each observation is assigned a weight of 1. If you specify more than one WEIGHT statement, then the last statement is used. The weights are normalized so that they add up to the actual sample size.

statements.name: WHEN
statements.description: Identifies SAS statements that are executed when a particular condition is true.

arguments.name: DO
arguments.description: Action statement.

statements.name: WHERE
statements.description: Selects observations from SAS data sets that meet a particular condition.
